What is rounding, and why do we round numbers?

Rounding means making a number simpler, but keeping its value close to what it was. We round numbers to make communication easier and simplify things. 

For example: what is the number of people in your village? When answering this question, we might round off to an approximate number and say "2 thousand". But, in reality, there might be 2,110 people. 

Notice how rounding helps us communicate more easily, and gives us a simpler sense of the size of the population. Although "2 thousand" is less accurate than "2,110", it is easier to use.

 

How do I round a number?

Depending on the desired accuracy, you will often be asked to round a number to a specific place. (If you need a reminder of the place names, take a look at this .) Here are the steps to take when rounding a number:

  • Decide which is the last digit to keep. This can be determined based on the place you want to round to.
  • Then, do one of two things based on the value of the next digit:
    • If it is less than 5, leave the original digit the same. (This is called "rounding down".)
    • If it is 5 or more, increase the original digit by 1. (This is called "rounding up".)
  • Finally, change all the digits to the right of the original digit to 0.

 

Example 1: Let’s round the number 95,382 to the nearest thousand. Following the steps above:

  1. Identify the digit corresponding to the thousands place. This is "5". 

     

  2. What do we do with the "5" digit? We look at the next one after it:

    If that digit is 0, 1, 2, 3 or 4, we keep the original digit as is. If it is 5, 6, 7, 8 or 9, we increase the original digit by 1. The number after our original digit is "3", so we keep the original digit as is.

  3. Change all numbers to the right of the original digit to 0.

     

So, the number rounded to the thousands place is 95,000 (or 95 thousand).

 

Example 2: Round 54,623 to the nearest hundred.

Answer:

  • Step 1: Identify the digit at the hundreds place. This digit is "6".
  • Step 2: In the original number, look at the digit that comes after "6". That digit is 2. Since it is less than 5, we keep the "6" as is.
  • Step 3: Change all numbers to the right of the "6" to zeros. This gives 54600.

Thus, the rounded number is 54,600.

 

Example 3: Round 57,981 to the nearest hundred.

Answer:

  • Step 1: Identify the digit at the hundreds place. This digit is “9”.
  • Step 2: In the original number, look at the digit that comes after "9". That digit is 8. Since it is 5 or more, we increase the original digit (9) by 1. Adding 9 to 1 makes 10. We carry over the 1 to the next higher place, and add it to 7 to get 8.
  • Step 3: Change all numbers to the right of the hundreds place to zeros. This gives 58,000.

So, the rounded number is 58,000.
